item.title: Early Career Resources
item.description: Links to resources that I've found helpful during my time exploring startups and research [Last updated 09/01/24].
item.dc:creator: Harmon Bhasin
item.content:encoded:
I’ve done a lot of exploring, and have had a lot of questions. Here are some of the resources that have answered my questions. I’ll try to update this post every now and then and put a timestamp for when I have most recently updated it. Comment below if you want me to annotate these lists with what I found to be valuable.

General

I highly recommend people spend time learning how to learn effectively1 . This skill transfers into practically all domains.

Books

  • Deep Work - Cal Newport

  • The 4 Hour Workweek - Tim Ferriss

  • The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck: A Counterintuitive Approach to Living a Good Life - Mark Manson

  • Lying - Sam Harris

  • Public Speaking for Success - Dale Carnegie

  • On Writing Well - William Zinsser

Tools

  • ChatGPT/Claude - Working alongside these models is the future. Find ways to integrate this into your current workflows, there are tons of tutorials online.

  • Obsidian - My preferred notetaking app. You can connect it with Zotero or other citation managers so that you can refer to papers/books/articles in your notes.

Startups

Most books or podcasts I’ve listened too haven’t been useful in practice (in my minimal startup experience). Most things are best learned by doing, but here were a few resources I found helpful.

Books

  • The Lean Startup - Eric Ries

  • Zero to One - Peter Thiel

  • Made to Stick - Chip Heath, Dan Heath

  • The Founder’s Dilemmas - Noam Wasserman

  • The 22 Immutable Laws of Marketing - Al Ries, Jack Trout

Blogs/Podcasts (mostly helped me generate ideas)

  • Paul Graham

  • The Tim Ferris Show - Tim Ferris

  • The Knowledge Project - Shane Parrish

Tools

  • AWS Startup Credit

  • Lean Canvas

Research

Most of these resources are oriented towards PhD students, however their contents are still applicable to undergrads. I also highly recommend starting a journal club with your friends.

General

  • A Survival Guide to a PhD - Andrej Karpathy blog

  • Career advice - Terrance Tao blog

  • How to request a letter of recommendation

  • BMI 883/884 - Professional Skills

  • Problem choice and decision trees in science and engineering

  • Ten simple rules for reading a scientific paper

  • Ten simple rules for choosing a PhD supervisor

  • More detail on picking PhD advisors

  • How to Solve It: A New Aspect of Mathematical Method - George Pólya

Presentation/Writing

  • Tips for Writing Technical Papers

  • Ten simple rules for structuring papers

  • Ten simple rules for effective presentation slides

  • Writing Science: How to Write Papers That Get Cited and Proposals that Get Funded - Joshua Schimel

  • The Scientist’s Guide to Writing - Stephen B Heard

Funding/Fellowships

  • Both

    • Which are the most generous and prestigious scholarships and fellowships?

  • Graduate

    • NSF GRFP

    • Hertz Fellowship

    • Soros

    • NDSEG

    • GEM

    • DOE CSGF

    • Draper

  • Undergraduate

    • NSF REU

Tools

  • Zotero - Citation manager

1

I have not tried all of these, however this would be a good place to start. I personally have found concept maps (also known as mind maps) to be a game changer.

item.title: Silence: My New Favorite Playlist
item.description: Cultivating valuable ideas through deliberate reflection
item.dc:creator: Harmon Bhasin
item.content:encoded:
If you're contemplating starting a blog, take the plunge. This is my first attempt, wish me luck.

I aim to make myself extremely valuable in a field. You may want to do the same. This will require the acquisition of both skills and knowledge. At that point, I imagine our greatest impact will come from carefully choosing which problems to solve and how to solve them.

But what if we valued our time right now the way we want it to be valued later? Then, I think we would give ourselves time to think hard about things, because that's how we'd generate value in the first place. Well, why wait?

My proposition is simple: give yourself downtime to think about anything. But importantly, avoid music, audiobooks, podcasts, or any other consumption of content during this time. Bask in the silence.

This “basking” led me to briefly explore measure theory, a branch of mathematics that formalizes the concept of measurement. Though my exploration was short-lived (I realized I was overcomplicating my study of probability ;)), it exemplifies how this practice has made me more receptive to pursuing random thoughts.

And just maybe, your next random thought will give you the idea to kickstart your career.

Give yourself two weeks. Start with 10-20 minutes, 2-3 times a week. You might be surprised by the ideas you generate.
